**Stock Price under MM Proposition I**



```{r}
#| eval: true
#| results: asis
#| echo: false
#| warning: false
library(webexercises)
set.seed(1003)
shares_without <- round(rnorm(1, mean = 2, sd = 1), 2)
price_per_share_without <- round(rnorm(1, mean = 24, sd = 1), 2)
shares_with <- round(rnorm(1, mean = 2, sd = 0.5))
debt_with <- round(rnorm(1, mean = 12, sd = 5))
interest_rate <- 0.05
value_without <- shares_without * price_per_share_without
equity_value_with <- value_without - debt_with
price_per_share_with <- equity_value_with / shares_with

```

Consider two firms, **Leverage** and **NonLeverage**, that have identical assets and generate identical cash flows.   NonLeverage is an all-equity firm with `r shares_without` million shares outstanding trading at `r price_per_share_without` per share.   Leverage has `r shares_with` million shares outstanding and `r debt_with` million in debt, with an interest rate of 5%.  Under **Modigliani–Miller Proposition I (no taxes)**, compute the **stock price for Leverage (in $)**.
